  <strong style="display: block;">What is the main limitation of using standard deviation (volatility) as a risk measure for a single stock in the context of a diversified portfolio?</strong>

  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q7" value="A"> A. Standard deviation is too difficult to calculate for individual stocks.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q7" value="B"> B. Standard deviation does not distinguish between upside and downside risk.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q7" value="C"> C. Standard deviation measures total risk, including diversifiable risk that is not relevant to a diversified investor.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q7" value="D"> D. Standard deviation is only applicable to bonds, not stocks.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q7" value="E"> E. Standard deviation assumes the expected return is always zero.</label><br>
</form>
